[LEXICON]: Archaic vocabulary may impede readability for modern readers.
[SYNTAX]: Occasionally overly complex sentence structures (e.g., lengthy embedded clauses).

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt transitions between critiques of Spencer’s narrowness and expert endorsements.
[CLARITY]: Assumes familiarity with Spencer’s works and historical context without explicit explanation.

[LEXICON]: Overly complex and repetitive terminology (e.g., vague uses of "force," "cause," "power").
[CLARITY]: Archaic vocabulary ("fain," "sanctioned by definition") and dense philosophical jargon.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shifts (e.g., quote about Matter/Mind, sudden critiques of terminology).
[STRUCTURE]: Tangential critiques (e.g., "Source" vs. "force") not fully integrated into the argument.
[LOGIC]: Overly defensive tone and unresolved ambiguities in Spencer’s concepts.

[SYNTAX]: Overly complex sentence structures impair readability.
[LEXICON]: Formal vocabulary may challenge comprehension for non-specialists.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shifts (e.g., introduction of Bergson’s doctrine, Russell/Mach tangent) disrupt flow.
[CLARITY]: Assumes prior knowledge of philosophical contexts without elaboration.

[SYNTAX]: Excessively long, convoluted sentence structures (e.g., "And when things stand in certain kinds of relatedness...")
[LEXICON]: Overuse of specialized philosophical/technical terminology without clarification (e.g., "quasi-mechanical type," "smudgy extension")

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt transitions between paragraphs (e.g., shift from energy discussion to Mill’s examples)
[CLARITY]: Assumes extensive background knowledge of Spencer, Mach, Russell, and Mill without contextualization

[SYNTAX]: Overly complex, lengthy sentences (e.g., "Much more analysis...") disrupting flow.
[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shifts between paragraphs (e.g., from "ground" concept to Spencer critique).

[STRUCTURE]: Assumed background knowledge (e.g., Spencer’s "First Principles" context).
[LOGIC]: Abrupt jumps (e.g., transition from relational types to crystal formation example).

[SYNTAX]: Overly complex sentence structures impeding readability.
[LEXICON]: Formal, dense vocabulary requiring concentrated effort.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shifts between paragraphs (e.g., introduction of Mill’s causation concept).
[CLARITY]: Assumes prior knowledge of referenced theorists (e.g., Spencer, Lewes) without contextualization.

[COMPLEXITY]: Overly complex sentence structures and dense technical vocabulary.
[REPETITIVENESS]: Repeated use of similar terminology (e.g., "states of consciousness," "subjective affections") without clear elaboration.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shifts between critiques of Spencer’s biology and philosophy of science (e.g., jump from "Dynamic Element in Life" to cognitive relations).
[CLARITY]: Assumes specialized knowledge of Spencer’s works and philosophical debates without contextualization.
[STRUCTURE]: Dense, unclear explanations (e.g., distinction between "vivid" and "faint" subjective affections).

[SYNTAX]: Overly complex sentence structures impair readability.
[LEXICON]: Some word choices (e.g., "effective relatedness") could be clarified for smoother flow.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shifts between concepts (e.g., Earth’s motion to cognition).
[STRUCTURE]: Ideas occasionally feel loosely connected despite logical progression.

[LEXICON]: Overly complex vocabulary and sentence structures may hinder smooth readability.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from criticizing Spencer to discussing gravitative vs. cognitive knowledge.
